segments.text: Okay.
Of course, at this time, the Army's advancement did basically depend on how many people were in rank at the time.
And if someone did die, then it was time for somebody else to move up because it was so frozen.
It was almost strictly seniority.
Yeah.
To further point that out, in 1940, when I went on active duty and joined the 7th Division,
Excuse me, Sixth Division.
In those days, we had Square Division.
We had an artillery regiment.
I was attached to a battery.
The battery commander was Captain Eaps.
Mind you now, this was 1940.
He was class of 27 at West Point.
Battery exec, First Lieutenant William O. Darby, who later became the name of the Darby's Rangers, the class of 1934.
But they were caught in the appropriations.
Our regimental commander, one of the toughest guys you ever saw, and the job called for a full colonel.
It was a major turn.
I'll give you some ideas.
What did you think of the professional soldiers that were at A&M at the time?
As a whole, I liked them.
We had a few of them.
I'm particularly fond of Lieutenant Jeff Vins, who was not only an excellent instructor, but he had a sense of humor.
One day he gave a true and false test.
And I marked it true and put in parentheses flip coin.
And he marked it x by and put in parentheses wrong side.
But we had equitation, and I enjoyed that.
In fact, our equitation instructor had a, well, his wife, the mayor,
And it was a beautiful horse.
And I happened to have a rather good seat on the horse.
Among other things, when I was in high school, we had a Calvary lieutenant who used to have equitation classes on Saturdays.
And I took that.
But this horse, when he jumped,
He'd stumble in the jumps.
And it took me three or four times riding him to find out what the problem was.
Normally, I don't know if you're familiar with horses or not, but horses have a right lead.
And you take them on the right and they jump, and their right foot is ahead and they jump.
This horse happened to have a left lead.
And when you went in from the right, the mayor changed and threw her off.
And I just go, you take her in from the left, where she was on the left lead.
And I jibbed her down.
But we had an excellent stable of horses.
Most of them were just army remasters.
And we'd be on them, and the instructor would say, they'd be in a circle, and he'd say, by the left flank, you can see those ears wiggle like that.
Oh, and they'd almost go by themselves.
But we jumped them through jumps.
We jumped through them blindfolded and took jackets off.
Here we go.
Did the professional officers, did they seem a little...
I'm not sure in those days.
Since World War II, ROTC duty has been part of their career advancement.
I'm not certain in those days.
In many instances, the commandant, who was chief of PMS&E, was probably on his last assignment in Norman's book.
He was probably on his last assignment, and I don't think that is too far from true now.
But we had some characters.
Yet they were very cooperative in many ways.
One year, we had an individual in there that obviously had one foot short of the other.
And he'd march in ranks, you know, and so forth.
began to get a little suspicious, I think I was a junior.
So we kept questioning him about, you know, what classes he would take and where his money came from.
He said he'd been disabled in the state after the state was banned.
So finally we went down to the commandant's office and he was just
He wasn't even registered.
He was just having a brief room tour.
So I went over to the commandant's office, knocked on the door, asking if he wanted to take care of it, if he wanted us to take care of it.
He said he'd be happy if we took care of it.
So we just very quietly went back and told him that when the daylight came, he better be gone.
But our tactical officers, for the most part, were able, dedicated people.
Not all of them.
Would you compare the quality of A&M grads with other ROTC graduates at other schools?
As a group, and I'm talking about myself,
group, they were heads and shoulders above all other ROPC officers.
As far as preparation, how about would you compare them with West Point grads?
On initial appointment as second lieutenant, they were ahead of West Point grads.
But you must remember that a West Point graduate's primary instruction was duty, honor, country, and an engineering degree.
The Army's system was, and it took me a number of years to grasp this, but I did.
The education produced the basic officer.
We felt like we knew more than West Point graduates, which we did because of our hands-on training at the college.
But the Army's theory then, and it is now,
that we can teach you that in basic brain schools and advanced brain schools and progress, and I have no quarrel with it.
So I have very great respect for all of the service academies.
They turn out some poor people as do other institutions, but as a whole,
I heard from some people that as far as promotion is concerned, there's sort of a West Point club.
We used to refer to it as WPPA, West Point Protective Association.
Do you think there is such a thing?
Not so much up to Lieutenant Colonel.
up to including lieutenant colonel.
Beyond that, there are fewer colonels.
If you look at the division, for example, there's approximately 26 lieutenant colonels, six full colonels, and three general officers.
The competition gets rough.
And I have seen it work.
Even when I was overseas, when the Army called me, when I was at the Corps headquarters, said, I've got a major so-and-so coming down to Vegas.
He said, he's a member of the WPPA, but he's a nice guy.
But when you get up to a colonel in general, then you're in direct competition with him.
I don't think that that applies...
quite as strong in the regular army.
So you think it's more a question of quality and the competition?
I think so.
There's still a little element of it that can't help but be an old school tie.
Yeah.
Is there a Texas A&M Protective Association?
Not that I know of, but they immediately recognized each other.

But one thing about the West Point graduate, particularly depending upon his ability and his course of action, one of the finest jobs that you could possibly have is a young lieutenant as an aide to a general officer.
They seem to get those jobs.
Is that what you're saying?
You get to know a lot of people.
Sometimes if you really get in a sticky situation, you can maybe call for some help from somebody that knows you.
You're not just a face.
But the Army has a rather rigid society, as does the university.
For example, an assistant professor's wife wouldn't dare call the dean's wife by her first name.
The military works the same way, and I think it's necessary.
But I have no quarrel with service captains.
But I have found that Texas A&M University graduates make fine officers, not in every case.
When you graduated from A&M, did you know what you wanted to do?
Yes, sir.
What was that that you wanted to do?
Have you ever heard of the Thomason Act?
Yeah, I have heard of the Thomason Act.
Do you know any background on it?
Yeah.
Did you want to become a regular officer under the Thomason Act?
The Thomason Act, if I may divert, there was a congressman named Ewing Thomason who later became a federal district judge in El Paso.
His son, Bill Thomason, lives in Bryan.
He's retired now.
He's an attorney.
But he owned the John Deere business for many years.
But he introduced a bill in Congress called, we refer to it as the Tonkin Act, in which case 1,000 reserve officers would be put on active duty for a year.
At the end of that time, 50 of them would be chosen for regular commissions.
I applied for that.
You're a senior here at A&M?
Yes.
My chief of section taught me how to do it.
I'm not certain Fireside was different, though.
And I'm sure he felt like he may have been just in a down period there, or his career wasn't going real well.
But I turned it down.
And then the next year, I reapplied.
And believe it or not, I didn't pass the physical.
due to an unfortunate set of circumstances.
I was living in Fort Worth, and I drove up Fort Sill, Oklahoma, and got the doctor off the golf course.
And he reported me as unstable blood pressure, which doesn't mean anything, and pigmented nevi, which is...
some of these spots here.
Of course, they had a lot of people to select from.
I went down to Fort Sam Houston, Texas.
This colonel in charge right away let me know that Major Brown was a competent doctor.
And I said, sir, I didn't come down here to run Major Brown down.
I came down to try to get in the Army.
So they ended up with
me laying naked on a table, my arm plunged in ice water to here, taking the blood pressure.
And then they discussed this multiple pigmented nevi.
And I could hear one say, well, Jack will be here in a minute.
We'll see what he says, who I assume was a dermatologist.
So this officer strolls in with a white jacket on, looks at one here.
Walked all the way around, got to the door, and turned around and said, not a damn thing.
But they couldn't get over it.
Unstable blood pressure.
Was it true?
I mean, every time they take your blood pressure, was it different?
Apparently so.
So they wouldn't let you in?
They had a number of options for them.
So what did you decide to do?
Find a job.
See, when I got here, I went to work for Oliver Farm Equipment Company in the Dallas range.
The jobs weren't easy.
No, no.
What were you doing?
A little bit of everything.
I was trying to design a system of making the plow go up and down automatically on the tractor.
The art of hydraulics needed World War II to bring it along.
The guy that had been working on it was doing it in the spring.
I could never prove it.
I finally ended up, I guess you'd say, in the accounting department.
But to show you how tough times were, I went to work $85 a month.
And that 30 days cut everybody in the branch 10%.
And after a year,
I left them.
I had worked over in Fort Worth in one of the farm stokers.
After a year, I left them and came back down here and went to the department head and interviewed and went to work with Wallace Black in Dallas.
And I stayed with them until
That was 37.
They were in 1940.
So you went active.
No, you went active in 1941.
Well, I went active in 1941.
I went on active duty in 1940.
But, see, I loved the engineering department.
I was up there about nine months.
At that time, they had a program, which they had stopped.
of taking engineers and sending them to Oil City, Pennsylvania for a year to go through the various departments where they're manufactured.
They had moved their main office to Dallas a few years before that.
Oil Supply Company is a wholly owned subsidiary of U.S. Steel, or was.
I enjoyed the engineering drafting department.
Our chief engineer,
Gus Meyer, and our chief craftsman, Hans Vogelgesang, were both born, raised, and university educated in Germany.
Hans and I became rather close friends, and I loved working there.
Then they sent me to the field as a service
And that's where I met my wife.
I was stationed in Graham, Texas.
And I went through the, I guess, West Wichita Hall, what they call the KMA.
And then they transferred me to Illinois.
And that was pure hell.
Why?
It was another book.
We were living in southern Illinois.
The winters were bitter and the summers were terribly hot.
I've been stuck six and seven times in one day.
I started at, oh well, $100 a month, which wasn't too bad.
When I went to Field and Graham,
I got all the way up to $115 a month.
When I transferred to Illinois, I was making $135 a month.
The conditions were terrible, and the pay was poor.
I was living in a boon town.
I was paying $35 a month rent.
And living conditions were poor, and I was married and everything else.
So finally, in 1940, I just went in to the district manager.
I made a noise and told him.
I was getting a 30-day notice.
And he immediately said, you're going to work with another supply company.
Because they had a little deed.
If I had quit them and gone to work for, say, Republic Supply Company, all they had to do is pick up the phone and tell them, call them, and say, hey, the whole hostel left us to go to work for you.
And they'd say, that's enough.
We'll take care of it.
I told them no.
I was going back to Texas.
Went by Fort Worth, the former store man in Wichita Falls, where we were doing a quarter million dollars a month, big money in those days.
the district manager.
And he said, go on over to Dallas and tell them you want to go to work at the bottom hole department.
I said, I don't know anything about bottom hole work.
He said, I'll teach you all you need to know.
I said, no.
I said, as far as I'm concerned, they're a bunch of so-and-sos, and I'm going to take them.
I came back here and went, no.
So did you work for your uncle now?
No.
A man by the name of O.B.
Donahue had worked for my father now.
He started to use carpenters.
And a few months later, Jutte came by and wanted to meet Jutte.
But
An interesting thing, when I moved to Illinois, I transferred my reserve affiliation from San Antonio to St. Louis.
All the time it was just paper outfit.
Even when I was in Texas, I would take the paper outfit.
So you never did any training from 1936 until 1940, really?
Extremely enough, I did.
Where I lived in Salem, Illinois, they had an infantry company of the 33rd Illinois National Guard.
I went out to see the company commander, and he said he didn't need any officers.
So I said, it would be all right if I just take my insignia off and just show up and drill with you.
He said, yeah, I'll be fine.
So they'd issue me a rifle, you know.
We'd be at formation, port on.
They'd call somebody else's name, and I'd put my rifle down.
I drove in, no pay, no recognition.
Why'd you decide to do that?
Keep my hand in there.
In 1940, you went active for a couple of weeks.
Oh, 30 days.
The reason I did that, number one, was in order to get promoted to first lieutenant.
I was ordered to Camp Jackson, South Carolina, and I was attached to the 6th Division.
And we stayed there a week, a week and a half, and we moved to Fort Benning, Georgia.
What I wasn't aware of, I was the second lieutenant, was that this was the pre-1940 Louisiana maneuvers.
And we marched around in the red clay of Georgia in the rain.
And some interesting highlights occurred.
The 1940 maneuvers, as far as I've ever been able to find out, were a fiasco in Louisiana that somehow both forces decided they were opposing overwhelming forces.
And as a result, they pulled so far back that they called it off.
But we had a bunch of old regular army people there.
One of the things that I always enjoyed was a regimental commander.
All of his messengers were out.
His flags were misplaced.
His telephone lines were cut, and he had an old hand-winding radio.
He radioed division headquarters and completely out of communication.
So when I played that tour duty, I came from behind.
How did the older actor
officers get along with a 30-day officer?
Is there any friction?
Not really.
They tolerate this, I'm sure, because we knew little or nothing.
At that particular time in Battery C,
We had, in addition to two or three of us, we had an even dozen pilots attached to us.
Randolph Field was in the air academy where all the pilot training took place.
And somebody got the brilliant idea, as they were wanting to do,
that in order for a pilot to support the ground troops, he needs to know how they lead.
So that graduating class, and it was one that somebody got married every 30 minutes to the chapel.
So they attached them to these various units that were going to be in Louisiana.
I might add as an aside, they hated every penny done.
We had a large battery mess there.
But Captain Eaps and Lieutenant Darby were very tolerant of us.
They didn't pay much attention to us because they had so many other things to share.
But I was made a forward observer, which I hadn't the faintest idea what a forward observer did.
I learned a lot from the sergeants.
which you can if you listen to them.
And I completed that Thursday tour of Goodyear.
And then you were promoted after that to first lieutenant.
Did you want to, at that point, did you want to stay in the service?
Did you want to come back in your automobile?
I meant to tell you something.
I'm not sure what I wanted to do then.
In 1940, I was knocked down.
really aware of the international situation.
I've often wondered had I acted on it at the foresight.
But St. Louis Reserve Headquarters started sending me letters about once every 30 days requesting that I transfer to the Army Air
and go on immediate active duty as a plant inspector, had I been aware of what the circumstances were.
See, they were getting called to guard, but I wasn't aware of that.
I was in rather an isolated world.
I probably would have taken it.
Where it had led, I don't know.
In 1941, what prompted me, they came out with what they call this year's active duty.
And I talked to my partner, and we agreed I'd go ahead and get it off.
So I went on duty April 15, 1941.
And my orders read that I'd be returned to my home of record by 15 April, 1941.
You returned in 1946.
That's right.
It's strange how the military works.
Well, sometime during that year, I got a notice from regimental headquarters asking to volunteer for three, six, nine, or 12 months of digital service.
I put a zero and sent it in.
Why is that?
Did you want to stand?
Well, I had a business going.
There wasn't any real evidence of war at the business school.
And some, what I would say, sizable investment at the time.
So I got called into the Adjutant's office, and he said, you can't do that.
So I think I selected six months.
Of course, it all went by the board in December 7.
But that was the original.
And of course, I went down to the San Antonio Reserve Headquarters and they said, well, we'll have to check the file.
They opened it up.
Of course, there wasn't anything in it.
I got my order a few days later.
So where was your first active duty station, 30th Field Artillery 1941?
Well, the first active duty station was Fort Art, California.
7th Division Artillery School that they formed.
Because all of us were assigned to the 26th Field Artillery Brigade.
And the 7th Division was instructed to set up this school to train these new coming officers.
And at that time, they had a 155 howitzer battalion and three historic horse-drawn light battalions, 74th, 75th, and 76th Real Artillery, who had been in the Meuse-Argonne Forest.
So they had brown horse batteries, black horse batteries.
This wasn't a year.
No, this was about six weeks.
Just shortly thereafter.
And then we went down to King Proverbs to form the 26th Field Artillery Brigade, which I was attached.
My initial assignment, I was TDY at 7th Division Artillery
My initial assignment was to the 155 Gun Regiment.
The brigade was two 155 Howard's Regiments and one 155 Gun Regiment.
And they were formed the Gun Regiment.
So I was reassigned to the 30th Field Artillery Regiment, one of the 155 Gun Regiments, Howard's Regiment.
No.
I've never fired a round of artillery in anger in my life.
I was reassigned as battery exec of the anti-tank battery.
And then in after December the 7th when
all hell broke loose on the West Coast.
In fact, one of the better things to do, we rushed up to San Jose State and Fort Ord and assembled four 75-millimeter guns.
Well, I'm not sure they knew what it was for.
But
Our anti-tank battery had to train those.
Two of those guns had French sights and two American sights.
So when you laid the battery, you'd say, gun number one, deflection 180.
Gun number two, deflection 183.
Gun number three, plateau 10, drum 10.
Gun number four, plateau 10, drum 16.
But our first job, two days after that, was to guard Moffett Field against a parachute attack.
There was a lot of fear of the Japanese who were going to invade out on the west coast.
Well, you know, some of them surfaced in Shelter Beach out there.
But after things settled down a little bit, oh, it was horrible, really.
They pulled us.
out all the anti-tank batteries.
And from it, we formed the 826th Tank Star Battalion.
And an interesting sidelight, General Jim Hannigan, who used to be Dean of Student Affairs, he was a battery exec, and I was S-4.
I went on active duty, and
April 15th, 41, and got promoted to captain in February of 42.
And Jim Hannigan and Doris White and I, we've known 35 years.
But...
Were you still on the California in February of 42?
Mm-hmm.
But during February 1942, they started to round up the Japanese Americans out there and send them to relocation centers.
Did you have anything to do with that?
No, we had some in and out.
We had a sergeant who was transferred out.
Now, he was in the military, so I think he went to that Japanese regiment.
I never did know what it was.
414, yeah.
But we had nothing to do with that.
We had our own job to do because we were essentially combat units.
And we formed the 826th Tank Squadron at that point.
And shortly thereafter, we pulled out of Camp Roberts and went down the march
It wasn't known as March Air Force Base now.
It was March Field then.
And the entire battalion at the guard post.
And I was officer of the day for 48 hours every 14 days.
I started out as F-4 and then I became company commander.
48 hours straight?
Yes, sir.
We're supposed to stay up?
I mean, were they not?
No, no.
No, you were officer today for 48 hours.
No, you got some sleep.
But the regulations then, you had to inspect the guard at periodic intervals.
And the regulations stated then, I think it had been slightly changed now, slightly altered.
Between midnight and daylight, you had to inspect it.
And off the Apache Mountains, it was cold.
I put on long underwear and short coat and climbed in that Jeep because it took a 17-mile ride to make off the coast.
And of course, they were absolutely frightened to death.
See, once the planes hit the coast, they could see Marchville.
And I forget what was there.
Sure enough, the alert was a blue alert.
They even blew a blue alert one night.
It was false, but it was hard.
And then on top of it, we got in 150 recruits, okay, direct from the river station.
So they were raw recruits that you had to train?
Yes, sir.
I had to take one of my...
company officers and put him in charge of it.
And we trained them for six weeks.
But they came right direct from the railroad station.
And we managed.
That was hard duty there.
What kind of equipment did you have as a tank destroyer?
How were you going to destroy the tanks?
Well, it was with a tank destroyer.
But first of all, I think we had some anti-tank guns.
But see, we went from there.
My sequence is correct.
back to Camp Roberts.
Then from Camp Roberts, we went to Fort Hood, Texas.
And Fort Hood was a foundation stone building, so we were out at the boondocks and the air land passes.
I remember a general came to visit us one day.
And he stood before our battalion and said he was going to take guns and guns to win this war.
And I could hear a soft little voice say, we're going to take a whole lot of guns from you guys.
So you were short on equipment?
Very short.
And it was somebody's theory that a tank destroyer would destroy tanks.
like a tank, but an open turret.
And we trained and trained and trained as that.
And we went to the Moabe Desert and went on summer maneuvers all over the desert, which was kind of fun, really.
You didn't get overseas until 1944.
Were you eager to get overseas as a unit?
You were basically trained that for three years.
Yes and no.
Because we trained and trained.
I went to advanced tank patrol school in Fort Hood.
And then the Army discovered that
They sent a few tank destroyers to Europe.
Then the Army discovered that the best tank destroyer was another tank.
So we were converted into the 826th Amphibious Tractor Battalion.
And why tractor?
Sir?
Why tractor?
Well, it's an entirely different mission.
These were known as amphibious tractors, same as which Marines landed in Guadalcanal.
And they needed some amphibious tractor battalions.
So after all that work and that, then we went to Fort Ord, California for amphibious training.
And we went overseas.
Now, did you have an opinion on where you'd rather fight, either in Europe or in the Pacific?
I guess I'm a soldier.
I go where I'm told to go.
In retrospect, I think I'd rather have fought in Europe, a civilized country.
By the same token, I'm alive, and I might have been dead.
Those South Pacific islands are not very attractive.
And I was in quite a few of them.
And our first hint of civilization
Well, let's continue the story then.
You went over in September of 1944.
That was your first overseas tour.
Where'd they send you?
The unit went ahead of me.
I stayed back in San Francisco.
Why?
To get the equipment.
Oh, okay.
I stayed back there for about 30 days.
It was a nice tour.
In fact, they were paying me $300 a month.
ration quarters to stay back.
I loaded with money.
I'd make an $800 a month major.
And see, I was a tax executive.
And so I joined them in the Admiralty Islands, which they had two islands, Los Negros and
Those islands are in Seattle Harbor.
Have you ever heard of Seattle Harbor?
No.
It's a huge, huge harbor.
It was supposed to have been discovered by the German raider in World War I, Captain Seattle.
You couldn't really put the whole city fleet in there until that wouldn't turn around.
And it was a major...
installation of the Navy.
In fact, they brought in a floating
